newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: TENNIS-ONDRUSKA GIVES S.AFRICA EDGE OVER RUSSIA.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-ONDRUSKA GIVES S.AFRICA EDGE OVER RUSSIA.

text.p: South Africa opened up a significant early lead over Russia before rain interrupted the opening singles matches of their Davis Cup World Group first round tie on Friday.

South Africa's number two player Marcus Ondruska gave his country the perfect start when he upset Russian number one Andrei Chesnokov 7-6 6-3 3-6 4-6 7-5 in a five-set marathon in the first match of the day.
The 24-year-old Ondruska, the world number 103, overcame his higher-ranked opponent after almost four hours of intense battle in extreme heat and humidity at the Westridge Park Stadium.
"That's one of the toughest matches I've ever played - it was incredibly humid out there," Ondruska said.
"The first two sets were pretty intense and I think I put in a lot more effort than he did. By the third set, I felt dead tired - and not at all healthy."

In the second rubber of the day, world number eight Wayne Ferreira was locked at five-games all in his opening set against Russian number two Andre Cherkasov when persistent rain finally ended play for the day.

Ferreira, ranked 112 places higher than Cherkasov, was 15-0 up on his own service game when the players were driven from the court by the second rain stoppage of the day. Their unfinished match continues on Saturday morning.
With on-court temperatures reaching 41 degrees celsius, Ondruska took the first two sets against Chesnokov in the opening rubber.
But the Russian, ranked 73 in the world, then clawed his way back into the match with some good passes and consistent serving to take the third anmd fourth sets 6-3, 6-4.
The fifth and final set began with both players exchanging a break of serve apiece before holding their respective serves to remain locked at five-all.

Chesnokov then double-faulted when 30-40 down in the 11th game to present Ondruska with a crucial 6-5 lead and the South African, playing with increased confidence, promptly held his serve to take the set 7-5 and the match.

"I felt like dead meat on the court - the heat was terrible," Chesnokov said. "Only once before, in Singapore, have I experienced heat as bad. I don't think I was in good shape today and he played much better than me over the last three games."
